data.title: David Cameron’s first two months as foreign secretary: ‘He’s loving it’
data.meta_description: No longer burdened by a constituency, the former prime minister is revelling in being the Foreign Office ‘grown up’ and overcoming his private sector setbacks
data.text:
Lord Cameron of Chipping Norton is yet to enjoy all the perks of being the foreign secretary.

Michael Gove — a man he once accused of behaving “appallingly” during the Brexit referendum — is living in One Carlton Gardens, the stuccoed mansion overlooking St James’ Park that serves as the foreign secretary’s official residence. Cameron is still living in Notting Hill and has no plans to move.

Meanwhile, Chevening, the foreign secretary’s 17th-century grace and favour home in Kent, is undergoing refurbishment, meaning the 57-year old has been unable to entertain visiting dignitaries in the sort of relaxed setting he liked to employ as prime minister. In 2015, Cameron hosted Xi Jinping at Chequers, the prime minister’s Buckinghamshire estate, famously treating the Chinese premier to
